title: How to Cook Kina

steps.headline: Insert a pair of sharp scissors into the center of the kina's shell.
steps.description: Wear a pair of thick gloves to prevent getting poked by the spines on the kina. Flip the kina over so that the flat side of the urchin is facing up. Press the sharp end of your scissors into the center of the shell until you penetrate it. Keep the kina on ice while you store it in the refrigerator. Kina will stay good for 2-3 days on ice.

steps.headline: Cut a hole in the kina.
steps.description: Make the hole large enough so that you can fit your fingers or a spoon inside of the hole. The shell itself should be easy to cut into.

steps.headline: Pour out the liquid in the hole.
steps.description: Turn the kina over into an empty bowl or your sink and drain the excess water from the urchin.

steps.headline: Remove the yellow parts of the kina.
steps.description: The yellow portions inside of the shell are edible and are usually referred to as kina tongues. Carefully pull them out of the shell with a spoon or your hands.

steps.headline: Rinse the yellow tongues in salt water.
steps.description: Pour a tablespoon of salt into a bowl filled with cold water. Thoroughly swish each piece of kina for 10-15 seconds. Set the tongues aside in a bowl after swishing them. You have now successfully shelled and cleaned your kina. You can eat the yellow parts of the kina raw. Kina is best served fresh. The tongues will go bad in a day if you don't eat them right after extracting them.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: Preheating the oven will ensure an even cook across you pie. If you don't preheat your oven the breadcrumbs on the pie won't get as crispy.

steps.headline: Lay down a layer of breadcrumbs in a pie pan.
steps.description: You can purchase breadcrumbs from the supermarket or you can make your own. Sprinkle a liberal amount in a pie dish or pan. This will serve as the bottom of your pie. Use a standard 9 inches (23 cm) pie dish.

steps.headline: Cover the breadcrumbs with 1/3 of your kina.
steps.description: You can either chop the tongues into pieces or lay the whole pieces of kina on top of the first layer of breadcrumbs. Only use 1/3 of your kina so that you can stack your pie in several layers.

steps.headline: Repeat the steps, creating several layers of kina and breadcrumbs.
steps.description: Continue to lay down layers of breadcrumbs and kina until you run out of kina. The top layer of the pie should be breadcrumbs.

steps.headline: Cover the top of the pie with raw chopped bacon.
steps.description: Chop up whatever kind of bacon you prefer and sprinkle the pieces on top of the pie. As the pie cooks, the bacon should crisp up.

steps.headline: Bake the pie at 350 °F (177 °C) for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Place your pie in the preheated oven and cook it for 30 minutes. The outside of the pie should look golden brown when it's done.

steps.headline: Remove the pie and let it rest for 5-10 minutes before eating it.
steps.description: Resting the pie will let the inside finish cooking and set the pie. Once the pie is done resting, you can cut slices and serve it. The pie tastes the best right after it has been cooked, but can be stored in the refrigerator for 1 to 2 days.

steps.headline: Pour the flour, baking powder, salt, and pepper in a bowl.
steps.description: Mix 1 cup (120 g) of flour with 1 teaspoon (4 g) baking powder. A teaspoon (4 g) of salt and pepper will add more flavor to the batter. Pour the dry ingredients into a bowl and use a fork to mix the ingredients together.

steps.headline: Mix 1/2 cup (125 ml) of milk and one egg into the bowl.
steps.description: Crack an egg over the bowl and then use a fork to whisk the egg into the dry ingredients. Then, measure 1/2 cup (125 ml) of milk and pour it into the bowl. Continue to mix the batter together until it forms a paste-like consistency. Make sure that there are no more lumps in your batter before moving on to the next step.

steps.headline: Fill a pot ⅓ of the way with vegetable oil.
steps.description: Use a deep and heavy cast iron or stainless steel pot to fry your urchin. If you have a deep fryer, you can use that as well. You can also use other cooking oils with a high smoke point, such as canola oil, grapeseed oil, or lard.

steps.headline: Bring the oil to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: Turn the burners on and use a cooking thermometer to ensure that the temperature of the oil is 350 °F (177 °C). If the oil is cooler than this, your kina will come out soggy. If the temperature is too high, your kina will burn. If you don't have a thermometer, you can pour a small amount of your batter into the oil. If it doesn't bubble, the oil is still too cool. If it bubbles a lot and starts to burn, you know the oil is too hot. Oil will start to let off smoke if your heating it up too much.

steps.headline: Coat the kina in the batter.
steps.description: Dip the kina into the batter with a slotted spoon or tongs so that there's an even layer coating it.

steps.headline: Dip the kina into the hot oil.
steps.description: Carefully put the kina into the hot oil with a pair of tongs or a slotted spoon. When the kina is submerged, the oil should start to bubble. Continue to cook the kina until they are golden brown. This usually takes 10-15 minutes. Don't overcrowd the pot or you kina won't cook evenly. If you have more kina than what will fit in your pot, fry the kina in separate batches.

steps.headline: Remove the kina from the pot and let them drain on paper towels.
steps.description: Remove the fried pieces of kina with a slotted spoon or tongs and place them on a plate lined with paper towels. Let the kina sit for 5-10 minutes before serving them. They will be very hot when you first take them out of the oil. Fried kina tastes best when eaten immediately after you cook it. However, you can store it in your refrigerator for one to two days if you have leftovers.

steps.headline: Spread the kina on slices of buttered bread.
steps.description: One of the most common ways to eat kina is to eat them raw on slices of buttered bread. If you want to add a crunch, you can toast your bread.

steps.headline: Put the raw kina in a salad.
steps.description: Create a salad using lettuce, tomatoes, onions, and whatever other vegetables that you like. Put the raw kina in the salad and toss it. Light vinaigrettes and slightly acidic dressings taste best with kina salads. Tomatoes, red onion, chiles, beans, and seaweed taste great with kina.

steps.headline: Put fried or raw kina in pasta.
steps.description: Create pasta as you normally would. You can use a red sauce or a butter sauce. Once the pasta is cooked, simply put the raw or fried kina pieces on top of the pasta and mix it in. This will give your pasta a kina flavor.
